reason.tex: %text A determinant is a collection of elements arranged in equal numbers of rows and columns. It could be $1\times 1$ (1 row, 1 column), $2\times 2$, $3\times 3$ or $n\times n$. Examples for how to compute the value of a determinant. % \begin{align} A&=\left|9\right|\implies |A|=9 \\ B&=\left|\begin{array}{cc}3 & 4 \\ 1 & 2\end{array}\right| \implies|B|=(3\times 2)-(1\times 4)=2 \\ C&=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}3 & 4 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 & 2\end{array}\right| =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}{\bf 3} & 4 & 1 \\ 2 & {\bf 1} & {\bf 0} \\ 2 & {\bf 1} & {\bf 2} \end{array}\right| \\ \implies|C|&= {\bf 3\cdot D_{11}}(-1)^{(1+1)}+4\cdot D_{12}(-1)^{1+2} +1\cdot D_{13}(-1)^{1+3}\\ \text{}&=3\times \left|\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ 1 & 2\end{array}\right| -4\times\left|\begin{array}{cc}2 & 0 \\ 2 & 2\end{array} \right| +1\times\left|\begin{array}{cc}2 & 1 \\ 2 & 1\end{array} \right| \\ \text{}&=3\times 3-4\times 4 +1 \times 0 = -7 \\ \end{align} \\ %text For larger determinants, continue along the same pattern. %
